segment.source: The {Binding} markup extension is converted at XAML load time into an instance of the Binding class.
segment.target: The {Binding} markup extension is converted at XAML load time into an instance of the Binding class.

segment.source: {Binding} markup extension
segment.target: {Binding} markup extension

segment.source: {Binding} markup extension
segment.target: {Binding} markup extension

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Note A new binding mechanism is available for Windows 10, which is optimized for performance and developer productivity.
segment.target: Note A new binding mechanism is available for Windows 10, which is optimized for performance and developer productivity.

segment.source: See {x:Bind} markup extension.
segment.target: See {x:Bind} markup extension.

segment.source: Note For general info about using data binding in your app with {Binding} (and for an all-up comparison between {x:Bind} and {Binding}), see Data binding in depth.
segment.target: Note For general info about using data binding in your app with {Binding} (and for an all-up comparison between {x:Bind} and {Binding}), see Data binding in depth.

segment.source: The {Binding} markup extension is converted at XAML load time into an instance of the Binding class.
segment.target: The {Binding} markup extension is converted at XAML load time into an instance of the Binding class.

segment.source: This binding object gets a value from a property on a data source.
segment.target: This binding object gets a value from a property on a data source.

segment.source: The binding object can optionally be configured to observe changes in the value of the data source property and refresh itself based on those changes.
segment.target: The binding object can optionally be configured to observe changes in the value of the data source property and refresh itself based on those changes.

segment.source: It can also optionally be configured to push changes in its own value back to the source property.
segment.target: It can also optionally be configured to push changes in its own value back to the source property.

segment.source: The property that is the target of a data binding must be a dependency property.
segment.target: The property that is the target of a data binding must be a dependency property.

segment.source: For more info, see Dependency properties overview.
segment.target: For more info, see Dependency properties overview.

segment.source: {Binding} has the same dependency property precedence as a local value, and setting a local value in imperative code removes the effect of any {Binding} set in markup.
segment.target: {Binding} has the same dependency property precedence as a local value, and setting a local value in imperative code removes the effect of any {Binding} set in markup.

segment.source: Sample apps that demonstrate {Binding}
segment.target: Sample apps that demonstrate {Binding}

segment.source: Download the Bookstore1 app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore1 app.

segment.source: Download the Bookstore2 app.
segment.target: Download the Bookstore2 app.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: propertyPath
segment.target: propertyPath

segment.source: A string that specifies the property path for the binding.
segment.target: A string that specifies the property path for the binding.

segment.source: More info is in the Property path section below.
segment.target: More info is in the Property path section below.

segment.source: bindingProperties
segment.target: bindingProperties

segment.source: propNamevalue\[, propNamevalue\]*
segment.target: propNamevalue\[, propNamevalue\]*

segment.source: One or more binding properties that are specified using a name/value pair syntax.
segment.target: One or more binding properties that are specified using a name/value pair syntax.

segment.source: propName
segment.target: propName

segment.source: The string name of the property to set on the Binding object.
segment.target: The string name of the property to set on the Binding object.

segment.source: For example, "Converter".
segment.target: For example, "Converter".

segment.source: value
segment.target: value

segment.source: The value to set the property to.
segment.target: The value to set the property to.

segment.source: The syntax of the argument depends on the property of Properties of the Binding class that can be set with {Binding} section below.
segment.target: The syntax of the argument depends on the property of Properties of the Binding class that can be set with {Binding} section below.

segment.source: Property path
segment.target: Property path

segment.source: PropertyPath sets the value of Path, which is the property that you're binding to (the source property).
segment.target: PropertyPath sets the value of Path, which is the property that you're binding to (the source property).

segment.source: You can mention the property name explicitly: .
segment.target: You can mention the property name explicitly: .

segment.source: Or you can omit it: .
segment.target: Or you can omit it: .

segment.source: The type of Path is a property path, which is a string that evaluates to a property or sub-property of either your custom type or a framework type.
segment.target: The type of Path is a property path, which is a string that evaluates to a property or sub-property of either your custom type or a framework type.

segment.source: The type can be, but does not need to be, a DependencyObject.
segment.target: The type can be, but does not need to be, a DependencyObject.

segment.source: Steps in a property path are delimited by dots (.), and you can include multiple delimiters to traverse successive sub-properties.
segment.target: Steps in a property path are delimited by dots (.), and you can include multiple delimiters to traverse successive sub-properties.

segment.source: Use the dot delimiter regardless of the programming language used to implement the object being bound to.
segment.target: Use the dot delimiter regardless of the programming language used to implement the object being bound to.

segment.source: For example, to bind UI to an employee object's first name property, your property path might be "Employee.FirstName".
segment.target: For example, to bind UI to an employee object's first name property, your property path might be "Employee.FirstName".

segment.source: If you are binding an items control to a property that contains an employee's dependents, your property path might be "Employee.Dependents", and the item template of the items control would take care of displaying the items in "Dependents".
segment.target: If you are binding an items control to a property that contains an employee's dependents, your property path might be "Employee.Dependents", and the item template of the items control would take care of displaying the items in "Dependents".

segment.source: If the data source is a collection, then a property path can specify items in the collection by their position or index.
segment.target: If the data source is a collection, then a property path can specify items in the collection by their position or index.

segment.source: For example, "Teams\[0\].Players", where the literal "\[\]" encloses the "0" that specifies the first item in a collection.
segment.target: For example, "Teams\[0\].Players", where the literal "\[\]" encloses the "0" that specifies the first item in a collection.

segment.source: When using an ElementName binding to an existing DependencyObject, you can use attached properties as part of the property path.
segment.target: When using an ElementName binding to an existing DependencyObject, you can use attached properties as part of the property path.

segment.source: To disambiguate an attached property so that the intermediate dot in the attached property name is not considered a step into a property path, put parentheses around the owner-qualified attached property name; for example, .
segment.target: To disambiguate an attached property so that the intermediate dot in the attached property name is not considered a step into a property path, put parentheses around the owner-qualified attached property name; for example, .

segment.source: A property path intermediate object is stored as a PropertyPath object in a run-time representation, but most scenarios won't need to interact with a PropertyPath object in code.
segment.target: A property path intermediate object is stored as a PropertyPath object in a run-time representation, but most scenarios won't need to interact with a PropertyPath object in code.

segment.source: You can usually specify the binding info you need using XAML.
segment.target: You can usually specify the binding info you need using XAML.

segment.source: For more info about the string syntax for a property path, property paths in animation feature areas, and constructing a PropertyPath object, see Property-path syntax.
segment.target: For more info about the string syntax for a property path, property paths in animation feature areas, and constructing a PropertyPath object, see Property-path syntax.

segment.source: Properties of the Binding class that can be set with {Binding}
segment.target: Properties of the Binding class that can be set with {Binding}

segment.source: {Binding} is illustrated with the bindingProperties placeholder syntax because there are multiple read/write properties of a Binding that can be set in the markup extension.
segment.target: {Binding} is illustrated with the bindingProperties placeholder syntax because there are multiple read/write properties of a Binding that can be set in the markup extension.

segment.source: The properties can be set in any order with comma-separated propNamevalue pairs.
segment.target: The properties can be set in any order with comma-separated propNamevalue pairs.

segment.source: Some of the properties require types that don't have a type conversion, so these require markup extensions of their own nested within the {Binding}.
segment.target: Some of the properties require types that don't have a type conversion, so these require markup extensions of their own nested within the {Binding}.

segment.source: Property
segment.target: Property

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Path
segment.target: Path

segment.source: See the Property path section above.
segment.target: See the Property path section above.

segment.source: Converter
segment.target: Converter

segment.source: Specifies the converter object that is called by the binding engine.
segment.target: Specifies the converter object that is called by the binding engine.

segment.source: The converter can be set in XAML, but only if you refer to an object instance that you've assigned in a {StaticResource} markup extension reference to that object in the resource dictionary.
segment.target: The converter can be set in XAML, but only if you refer to an object instance that you've assigned in a {StaticResource} markup extension reference to that object in the resource dictionary.

segment.source: ConverterLanguage
segment.target: ConverterLanguage

segment.source: Specifies the culture to be used by the converter.
segment.target: Specifies the culture to be used by the converter.

segment.source: (If you're setting Converter.) The culture is set as a standards-based identifier.
segment.target: (If you're setting Converter.) The culture is set as a standards-based identifier.

segment.source: For more info, see ConverterLanguage
segment.target: For more info, see ConverterLanguage

segment.source: ConverterParameter
segment.target: ConverterParameter

segment.source: Specifies the converter parameter that can be used in converter logic.
segment.target: Specifies the converter parameter that can be used in converter logic.

segment.source: (If you're setting Converter.) Most converters use simple logic that get all the info they need from the passed value to convert, and don't need a ConverterParameter value.
segment.target: (If you're setting Converter.) Most converters use simple logic that get all the info they need from the passed value to convert, and don't need a ConverterParameter value.

segment.source: The ConverterParameter parameter is for moderately advanced converter implementations that have more than one logic that keys off what's passed in ConverterParameter.
segment.target: The ConverterParameter parameter is for moderately advanced converter implementations that have more than one logic that keys off what's passed in ConverterParameter.

segment.source: You can write a converter that uses values other than strings but this is uncommon, see Remarks in ConverterParameter for more info.
segment.target: You can write a converter that uses values other than strings but this is uncommon, see Remarks in ConverterParameter for more info.

segment.source: ElementName
segment.target: ElementName

segment.source: Specifies a data source by referencing another element in the same XAML construct that has a Name property or x:Name attribute.
segment.target: Specifies a data source by referencing another element in the same XAML construct that has a Name property or x:Name attribute.

segment.source: This is often use to share related values or use sub-properties of one UI element to provide a specific value for another element, for example in a XAML control template.
segment.target: This is often use to share related values or use sub-properties of one UI element to provide a specific value for another element, for example in a XAML control template.

segment.source: FallbackValue
segment.target: FallbackValue

segment.source: Specifies a value to display when the source or path cannot be resolved.
segment.target: Specifies a value to display when the source or path cannot be resolved.

segment.source: Mode
segment.target: Mode

segment.source: Specifies the binding mode, as one of these strings: "OneTime", "OneWay", or "TwoWay".
segment.target: Specifies the binding mode, as one of these strings: "OneTime", "OneWay", or "TwoWay".

segment.source: These correspond to the constant names of the BindingMode enumeration.
segment.target: These correspond to the constant names of the BindingMode enumeration.

segment.source: The default depends on the binding target but in most cases it is "OneWay".
segment.target: The default depends on the binding target but in most cases it is "OneWay".

segment.source: Note that this differs from the default for {x:Bind}, which is "OneTime".
segment.target: Note that this differs from the default for {x:Bind}, which is "OneTime".

segment.source: RelativeSource
segment.target: RelativeSource

segment.source: Specifies a data source by describing the position of the binding source relative to the position of the binding target.
segment.target: Specifies a data source by describing the position of the binding source relative to the position of the binding target.

segment.source: This is expressed in terms of the run-time object graph, for example specifying the object's parent.
segment.target: This is expressed in terms of the run-time object graph, for example specifying the object's parent.

segment.source: Setting the {RelativeSource} markup extension.
segment.target: Setting the {RelativeSource} markup extension.

segment.source: Source
segment.target: Source

segment.source: Specifies the object data source.
segment.target: Specifies the object data source.

segment.source: Within the Binding markup extension, the Data binding in depth.
segment.target: Within the Binding markup extension, the Data binding in depth.

segment.source: TargetNullValue
segment.target: TargetNullValue

segment.source: Specifies a value to display when the source value resolves but is explicitly null.
segment.target: Specifies a value to display when the source value resolves but is explicitly null.

segment.source: UpdateSourceTrigger
segment.target: UpdateSourceTrigger

segment.source: Specifies the timing of binding source updates.
segment.target: Specifies the timing of binding source updates.

segment.source: If unspecified, the default is Default.
segment.target: If unspecified, the default is Default.

segment.source: Note If you're converting markup from {x:Bind} to {Binding}, then be aware of the differences in default values for the Mode property.
segment.target: Note If you're converting markup from {x:Bind} to {Binding}, then be aware of the differences in default values for the Mode property.

segment.source: Converter, ConverterLanguage and ConverterLanguage are all related to the scenario of converting a value or type from the binding source into a type or value that is compatible with the binding target property.
segment.target: Converter, ConverterLanguage and ConverterLanguage are all related to the scenario of converting a value or type from the binding source into a type or value that is compatible with the binding target property.

segment.source: For more info and examples, see the "Data conversions" section of Data binding in depth.
segment.target: For more info and examples, see the "Data conversions" section of Data binding in depth.

segment.source: Source, RelativeSource, and ElementName specify a binding source, so they are mutually exclusive.
segment.target: Source, RelativeSource, and ElementName specify a binding source, so they are mutually exclusive.

segment.source: Tip If you need to specify a single curly brace for a value, such as in Path or ConverterParameter, then precede it with a backslash: .
segment.target: Tip If you need to specify a single curly brace for a value, such as in Path or ConverterParameter, then precede it with a backslash: .

segment.source: Alternatively, enclose the entire string that contains the braces that need escaping in a secondary quotation set, for example .
segment.target: Alternatively, enclose the entire string that contains the braces that need escaping in a secondary quotation set, for example .

segment.source: Examples
segment.target: Examples

segment.source: The second example sets four different Binding properties: ElementName, Path, Mode and Converter.
segment.target: The second example sets four different Binding properties: ElementName, Path, Mode and Converter.

segment.source: Path in this case is shown explicitly named as a Binding property.
segment.target: Path in this case is shown explicitly named as a Binding property.

segment.source: The Path is evaluated to a data binding source that is another object in the same run-time object tree, a Slider named .
segment.target: The Path is evaluated to a data binding source that is another object in the same run-time object tree, a Slider named .

segment.source: Note how the Converter property value uses another markup extension, {StaticResource} markup extension, so there are two nested markup extension usages here.
segment.target: Note how the Converter property value uses another markup extension, {StaticResource} markup extension, so there are two nested markup extension usages here.

segment.source: The inner one is evaluated first, so that once the resource is obtained there's a practical IValueConverter (a custom class that's instantiated by the element in resources) that the binding can use.
segment.target: The inner one is evaluated first, so that once the resource is obtained there's a practical IValueConverter (a custom class that's instantiated by the element in resources) that the binding can use.

segment.source: Tools support
segment.target: Tools support

segment.source: Microsoft IntelliSense in Microsoft Visual Studio displays the properties of the data context while authoring {Binding} in the XAML markup editor.
segment.target: Microsoft IntelliSense in Microsoft Visual Studio displays the properties of the data context while authoring {Binding} in the XAML markup editor.

segment.source: As soon as you type "{Binding", data context properties appropriate for Path are displayed in the dropdown.
segment.target: As soon as you type "{Binding", data context properties appropriate for Path are displayed in the dropdown.

segment.source: IntelliSense also helps with the other properties of Binding.
segment.target: IntelliSense also helps with the other properties of Binding.

segment.source: For this to work, you must have either the data context or the design-time data context set in the markup page.
segment.target: For this to work, you must have either the data context or the design-time data context set in the markup page.

segment.source: Go To Definition (F12) also works with {Binding}.
segment.target: Go To Definition (F12) also works with {Binding}.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can use the data binding dialog.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can use the data binding dialog.
